titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Went this morning and delivered to Mr: Van Leyden, my letter to the Committee of foreign affairs in reply to theirs relative to the affair of the Wilmington Packet &c. Conversation with him. Account of it in my letters.— Called on Mr: Levsen.— Long walk with him. Overtaken by the rain.— Evening at the Play. Clairette et Paulin ou les deux Espiegles.— La Mélomanie— Music of both tolerable.

2. Writing to the Secretary of State.— Walk to the barrier of the wood in the Rain. Read Dalrymple’s travels in Spain and Portugal. No information to be got from them.— Hirtius Commentaries on the Alexandrian War.

3. Rainy morning again.— Writing.— Walk to the Barrier.— Bielfeld called on me at the beginning of the Evening. We went together to Mr: Noël’s party.— Very numerous company.— Noel says that he used to write a great deal in Latin, and could write it with more ease than his native language.

4. Variable Rain and Sunshine.— Met Bielfeld and walked with him in the wood. Dined at the Baron de Schubart’s. Large company.— Mr: Goldberg asked me whether I could furnish him any account of the Bank of the United States and the principles of the institution. Promised to lend him the law by which it is established, and the report of Mr: Hamilton proposing it.— Noël was in high Spirits. said they had good news. Details of an action in which the french had taken many prisoners, and five superior officers. As to Moreau’s affair, it was undecided.— He expected every day to hear of the surrender of Mantua.— At table however he expressed his dissatisfaction that the Constitution which is to be reported on the 10th: instt: retains the demarcations of the Provinces. Said they ought all to be dissolved into a single body.— “Diable! comme vous y alléz!” said Hahn. “This however, said the other is only the opinion of the Citoyen Noël. The Minister you may be sure will find every thing you choose to do, excellent.”— He repeated this distinction, between himself the citizen and himself the citizen Minister five or six times, as if it was a thing very clear in his mind, but which required minute explanation to meet the intelligence of his hearers. I believe they hear enough of the Minister’s ill humour, officially.— No said Hahn if the Minister was to speak vous sentéz bien que je me tairois.— True enough.—
Somebody said. “The Minister is not here.” The idea might have occurred before, to Noël himself.— They drank for a Toast, the restoration of the finances, and Noël laughed very heartily. The subject cannot in his mind be susceptible of serious discussion.— Evening at Mr: Veerman’s— Music.

5. Bad night.— Weather dull. Long walk across the downs, and thence on the beach to Scheveling. Evening at the Play. L’Amant Jaloux. and Nina, ou la folle par Amour. both Musical pieces. A new Actress by the name of Durivier.— “She must be old, very old.” Found Bielfeld there. He goes with M. de Schubart, to-morrow morning into the Country.

6. Called on Mr: Levsen, between 11 and 12. long walk with him through Loosduynen, but went and returned by a road, which was before unknown to me. He shew me what has the appearance of being the ruins of an old fort, though it is scarcely possible to imagine why a fort should ever have been built in that spot. Evening at Madam Cneiff’s. Company not very numerous. Cards. Quadrill with a couple of Ladies whom I knew not.

7. Sale of books. Attended, but the books in general are quite indifferent. Weather dull. Walk alone through Ryswick, and at some distance on a road leading from thence. Returned by the same Way. Met Mr: Levsen, on my return. Evening at Mlle: Laurenzi’s.— Baron de Bonstettin. Cards. Whist with Madam Cneiff, Reuterswerd, and Sir Robert Barclay, an Englishman. I know not how he obtains permission to be here, and to pass to and from England as he has repeatedly done within these eighteen months.— Visit from

8. At the Sale again. purchased a few books. Found Mr: Levsen there. Walk with him in the bye-path back of Ryswick; a pleasant walk with which I was not before acquainted.— When I came home, had a visit from young Parkman.— Read this Evening the Commentaries upon the Spanish War, which are printed with those of Caesar. With them the book finishes.— The seven first books of the Wars in Gaul are the undisputed Work of Caesar himself. The three books of the Civil Wars bear his name, but their authenticity is questioned by the critics. The eighth book of the Gallic Wars, those of the Alexandrian and African Wars are a continuation attributed generally to Hirtius. This book upon the Campaign in Spain against the Sons of Pompey, is by a different and very inferior hand.
9. Sale in the morning. Short walk with Mr: Levsen. Parkman dined with us.— His conversation indifferent. Evening again at home, and dull.— Reading Cicero’s familiar Epistles.

10. This being the day fixed for the report of a Constitution to be made to the national Assembly, I attended the meeting. Found Mr: Bosset there. The credentials were read of a Minister Plenipotentiary from Spain, who arrived last Evening, and this morning presented them to the President. He came soon after into the lodge, as did M. de Schubart and Noël, Reuterswerd and the Counseller Scholten. Noël introduced the Spanish Minister, the Chevalier d’Anduaga.— The Constitution was produced between 1 and 2. The chairman of the Committee made a speech on producing it, which the President answered. The Substituted members took their leave in withdrawing
from the deliberations of the Assembly. Lublink in their name made a speech. It was resolved to read the Constitution on Monday. One of the members of the Committee, Van der Kasteele announced that he should oppose its adoption, as it was not founded on the principles of Unity and Indivisibility. A Warm debate then arose upon the question whether it should be read immediately, or on Monday. The debate was at length adjourned till to-morrow morning.— Bielfeld called on me in the Evening. He returned last night with M. de Schubart from the Country.— Evening at Mr: Noël’s party. Company numerous. Long conversation with Mr: Goldberg. Says they have spent here more than seventy millions of florins since September of the last year.

11. Long walk in a road beyond Ryswick, where I had not been before. Came out not far from Delft in a yard belonging to a Gentleman’s house.— Conversation with him. Took me for an Englishman. Crossed the canal in a boat and returned home by the public road.— Mr: Bourne here in the afternoon. Evening at Mr: Scholten’s. The Lustre on the point of breaking down— Saved however without any harm done. Cards— Quadrill with Mr: Euler and others unknown. Home at about ten. Prefer these parties much to those of late Suppers.

12. Mr: Bourne here in the morning, & Went to Rotterdam.— Books for Madame de Schubart. Letters for London; sent them in the Evening to Mr: Bourne upon his return.— Walk in the wood. At the play. Found Madam Veerman & her husband there. Les Pretendus. Music very good. Les Visitandines; performed better than I expected.— Went too late.

13. Letter to Pitcairn. Long walk over the bridge opposite the Ryswick Church round untill I came out in the back road to the House in the Wood. Another pleasant walk which I have not known before. Wrote a little in the Evening, and read a book of Cicero’s Epistles. Have intermitted my studious Evenings of late so much as to return to them with pleasure.

14. Sale of books again at Wetter’s.— Day for the reading of the Constitution in the Assembly. Wrote in the morning.— Early Dinner.— Mr: Levsen called on me between 3 & 4. to enquire if I knew what was done in the Assembly. Walk to Loosduynen.— Bielfeld called in the Evening. Read the 3d: book of Cicero’s Epistles ad familiares. written all to Appius Claudius Pulcher.

15. At the sale a short time in the forenoon— Writing.— At the Assembly. They are still reading the Constitution.— Walk to the barrier in the wood before dinner to the bridge near the Delft barrier in the afternoon.— 4th: Book of Cicero’s Epistles. principally to Servius Sulpicius and M. Marcellus. Two or three excellent Letters from Sulpicius. Read also the Oration for Marcellus, the superlative merit of which I was more able to perceive than I have ever been before. It is admirable in every point of view.— Part of Plutarch’s life of Cicero.

16. Sale for a few minutes.— At the Assembly— They were on business of little importance. Writing. An Early mooning.— Walk in the wood. Met Bielfeld on my return. He has read the Constitution, and thinks it pitiful. Walk in the afternoon towards Voorburg.— 5th: book of the familiar Epistles. To Metellus, Vatinius, Lucceius Rufus & others. The famous Letter to Lucceius in which he requests him to write memoirs of his (Cicero’s) consulate, and to disregard the laws of Historical veracity, in his favour, is among them.— A couple of curious letters also from Vatinius.

17. Stormy day. Purchased some books at the. sale. Visit from Mr: Wambersie a Citizen of Georgia, with a letter of recommendation from W. Clarke.— In difficulty respecting the sale of some Lands in Georgia, and wishes me to help him out of it. Told him I would see Mr: Schimmelpenninck, but apprehended I could be of little or no service to him in this affair. Called on Bielfeld, and walk with him.— Sale afternoon. Evening 6th: book of Cicero’s Epistles, addressed principally to the exiles of Pompey’s party, after Caesar’s victories in the civil War. To Torquatus, Caecina, Ligarius Trebianus and others. His letter of Divination to Caecina, is specially curious; that of Caecina to him is equally so.— He speaks of his Orator, and says that book may be taken as the test, whereby he is willing that his talents be tried.— He speaks of the timidity attributed to his character and justifies it with a great appearance of reason. The occasion and the Event serve at least to make it excusable.

18. Classical books sold this day but they went at too high prices.— Called on Mr: Schimmelpenninck and had some conversation upon Mr: Wambersie’s affairs. Rainy and stormy weather. Read in the Evening the 7th. book of Cicero’s Epistles. Those to Trebatius have considerable humour. The wit however is sometimes coarse.

19. Weather such as is peculiar to the Season and to the Country. Very unpleasant. Walk with Bielfeld, and afterwards a long one to Voorburg alone. Read the 8th. book of the familiar Epistles. It is altogether composed of those written from Coelius to Cicero. I find them very hard to understand. The book gave me more than five hours of steady attention.

20. Cool, but tolerable weather. Wrote a little in the forenoon. Walk to Loosduynen. Evening at the 9th: book of the Epistles. Those to Varro are ambitious of elegance and loaded with Greek. Those to Papirius Paetus, are all facetious. But they are so stuffed with cookery, that I have found none of them more perplexing. That upon the subject of obscene words is particularly remarkable for the manner in which he treats it. The Correspondence with Dolabella, leaves a question how it happened that they preserved their intimacy after the divorce of Tullia from her husband.

21. Mr: Havart called here in the morning. Walk to Loosduynen.— At the Assembly an hour. Heard the close of a speech of Weede, and the beginning of that of Schimmelpenninck. They write before-hand all their speeches upon affairs of any importance and read them from the tribune. The question now under consideration is whether they shall debate the Constitution lately reported, or reject it at once. There is not much eloquence among them.— Dined at Mr: Noël’s. A Dinner of Ceremony given to the Spanish Minister d’Anduaga, on his arrival. All the diplomatic corps and the Committee there. The Minister’s Lady; Madame Bosset, and Madam Van der Goes wife of a former Minister from this Country to Denmark.— I was seated next to Mr: De Sitter a Member of the Committee. He is federally inclined. A pleasant and moderate man. Hinted that the secret motives of the One and indivisibles is easily seen through.— Evening at the Comedy. Le Philosophe Imaginaire an Opera. Music of Paësiello, and very good. Plot similar to part of the Bold stroke for a wife.— La Revanche forcée, a pleasant little comedy in dialogue and vaudevilles. performance better than usual.

22. Walk across the downs to the beach beyond Scheveling.— At the Assembly. Heard two or three speeches, not remarkable. Visit from Mr: Calhoun. He has been to America since I saw him in London, the last Winter, and has lately arrived at Rotterdam. Intends now to reside some years in England— Dined
with him at the Lodgement of Rotterdam, by invitation of Mr: Havart. He went in the Evening with my brother to the subscription Ball; which opens this Evening for the Season.— At the play again. Le Deserteur. Le Tableau parlant. performance rather dull.

23. Wrote a little— Walk with Bielfeld in the wood. Mr: Calhoun and Mr: Havart dined, with us. They went in the Evening to the Dutch subscription play.— I pass’d it at Madam Cneiff’s. The company quite numerous. Cards.— Quadrill with Madam Bosset. M. Pallavicini and Mr: Levsen.— Not perfectly well.— Renewing the practice of early rising.

24. Writing and walk in the forenoon. Half an hour in the Evening at Mr: Noël’s party. Company large. Read the 10th: book of Cicero’s familiar Epistles. They are written after the Death of Caesar, to Plancus Pollio, Trebonius and others when Cicero had again engaged himself deeply in the affairs of the Republic and was endeavouring to restore a regular liberty.— They are interesting as historical monuments, but less entertaining than many of the preceding books.—

25. Letter to Mr: Luzac.— And began one to my father.— Unwell.— Want of exercise.— Letter from Mr: De Wolf relative to the payment of his interest the 1st: of next month. Answer; and to the Bankers at Amsterdam.— 11th: book of the Epistles. Similar to the last. Correspondence principally with Decimus Brutus, after the Death of Caesar. There is a letter to Matius, and his answer which deserve notice. Matius justifies his attachment to Caesar, which at that time made him obnoxious. He says he has not attained that degree of wisdom to rejoyce at the Death of his friend, because patriotism must be preferred to friendship.

26. Bielfeld called on me this forenoon. Walk with him in the wood. Agreed very well with him this Time. Discussed the morality of Cato’s Death.— Evening at the Play. Le Sourd et l’Aveugle. dull buffoonery.— La Pauvre femme.— Occasional anti-terrorist stupidity, about the neuf Thermidor.— La Revanche forcée. Not so well performed as the last time. Began the 12th. book of Cicero’s Epistles.

27. Writing in the forenoon. Long walk alone. Find my health suffering. Determined on a tour to Amsterdam.— Finished reading the 12th. book of Cicero’s Epistles. The subjects are principally similar to those of the preceding book. They are written to Cassius, Lentulus and Cornificius, in the interval between the Death of Caesar and the Second triumvirate.
28. Writing to W. Cranch, in answer to a Letter which I received yesterday from him. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. Music as usual.

29. Walk with Mr: Levsen. Weather very cold. Dined at Mr: Van Leyden’s. Diplomatic entertainment for the Spanish Minister.— Letter from Pitcairn; and from Mr: De Wolf. Answered the last. Both occasion much anxiety.— Evening at the french Comedy. But went quite late. A foolish Harlequinade, and Les Visitandines in three acts. The third foisted in, so as to destroy the merit of a very good play. House fuller than I ever saw it before. Benefit of Baptiste.

30. At 7. this morning, took the boat for Leyden, with my brother, and Whitcomb. arrived between 10 and 11. Put up at the Golden Lion.— Called on Mr: Luzac, and had considerable conversation with him.— Went to see the picture of Luke of Leyden, in the State house. It is about 15 years, since I saw it there before. The subject is the day of Judgment. The painting is very old, and in great preservation. The Painter had more imagination than taste. The reprobates are pitched by Devils into the mouth of an enormous shark.— Called in the afternoon upon Mr: Van Heukelem but he was not at home. Evening and supper at Mr: Luzac’s. Very pleasing and interesting conversation with him. Gave me his Discourse de Socrate in the Dutch Edition.

Day. Rise generally at about 7. Sometimes earlier. Translate a page from Tacitus, and study him till 9. Breakfast.— Write. attend to business and walk till between 3 & 4. Dine. From 5 till 10. in company or reading. Cicero’s Epistles. Light supper. Segar and bed at about 11. This mode of life does not perfectly suit my health which is one reason for my present tour.
